prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Frequency setup The main molecular line to observe is C18O (2-1), which can trace the protostellar envelopes as shown in our SMA results. 13CO (2-1), SO (5_6-4_5), CO (2-1), and N2D+ (3-2) will be observed simultanesously. 13CO (2-1), which is more optically thick than C18O (2-1), can trace outer layers of the protostellar envelopes. SO (5_6-4_5) can be associated with the transitional region from infalling envelopes to disks as seen in our ALMA cycle 0 results, and can be used to trace outer boundary of disks (if presents). 12CO (2-1) can traces the molecular outflows to better determine the rotational axes of the protostellar envelopes. N2D+ (3-2) can help to trace inner denser parts of the protostellar envelopes.
2. Angular Resolutions The precision of measuring emission peak position is better than spatial resolutions approximately by a factor S/N. Our imaging simulations show that with a spatial resolution of 100 AU and S/N of 10, our method can reveal rotational profiles down to the disk-forming region at 10 AU scale. Hence, we aim to achieve an angular resolution of 0.67", corresponding to 100 AU in these targets. The outer part (>8") of the protostellar envelopes has been probed with our SMA observations. In these ALMA observations we focus the inner <8" regions, and ACA or multiple configurations are not required.
3. Velocity Resolutions The rotational velocities in the envelopes around our targets are expected to be ~0.2 km/s at a radius of 100 AU, if the envelopes are spinning up. Hence, a spectral resolution of 122 kHz, resulting in a velocity resolution of ~0.17 is required to measure the rotational motions. If the envelopes are spinning down, with the proposed ALMA observations we can put 10 times more stringent constraints on the specific angular momenta of the envelope rotation at 100 AU scale, as compared to our SMA results.
4. Sensitivity We aim to achieve S/N of 10 to measure the rotational profiles down to 10 AU scale. The expected C18O (2-1) line intensity per beam is estimated from our SMA C18O (2-1) results assuming the intensity is uniformly distributed in our SMA beams.

1. Frequency setup The main molecular line to observe is C18O (2-1), which can trace the protostellar envelopes as shown in our SMA results. 13CO (2-1), SO (5_6-4_5), CO (2-1), and N2D+ (3-2) will be observed simultaneously. 13CO (2-1), which is more optically thick than C18O (2-1), can trace outer layers of the protostellar envelopes. SO (5_6-4_5) can be associated with the transitional region from infalling envelopes to disks as seen in our ALMA cycle 0 results, and can be used to trace outer boundary of disks (if presents). 12CO (2-1) can traces the molecular outflows to better determine the rotational axes of the protostellar envelopes. N2D+ (3-2) can help to trace inner denser parts of the protostellar envelopes.
2. Angular Resolutions In B335, there is a compact (~60 AU) component seen in millimeter dust continuum emission. To have more data points and reveal the rotational profile of the corresponding gas component, we aim to achieve an angular resolution of 0.4", corresponding to 60 AU, and apply our method. The outer part (>4") of the protostellar envelopes has been probed with our SMA observations. In these ALMA observations we focus the inner <4" regions, and ACA or multiple configurations are not required.
3. Velocity Resolutions The rotational velocities in the envelopes around our targets are expected to be ~0.2 km/s at a radius of 100 AU, if the envelopes are spinning up. Hence, a spectral reslotuion of 122 kHz, resulting in a velocity resolution of ~0.17 is required to measure the rotational motions. If the envelopes are spinning down, with the proposed ALMA observations we can put 10 times more stringent constraints on the specific angular momenta of the envelope rotation at 100 AU scale, as compared to our SMA results.
4. Sensitivity We aim to achieve S/N of 10 to measure the rotational profiles down to 10 AU scale. The expected C18O (2-1) line intensity per beam is estimated from our SMA C18O (2-1) results assuming the intensity is uniformly distributed in our SMA beams.

1. Frequency setup The main molecular line to observe is C18O (2-1), which can trace the protostellar envelopes as shown in our SMA results. 13CO (2-1), SO (5_6-4_5), CO (2-1), and N2D+ (3-2) will be observed simultaneously. 13CO (2-1), which is more optically thick than C18O (2-1), can trace outer layers of the protostellar envelopes. SO (5_6-4_5) can be associated with the transitional region from infalling envelopes to disks as seen in our ALMA cycle 0 results, and can be used to trace outer boundary of disks (if presents). 12CO (2-1) can traces the molecular outflows to better determine the rotational axes of the protostellar envelopes. N2D+ (3-2) can help to trace inner denser parts of the protostellar envelopes.
2. Angular Resolutions The precision of measuring emission peak position is better than spatial resolutions approximately by a factor S/N. Our imaging simulations show that with a spatial resolution of 100 AU and S/N of 10, our method can reveal rotational profiles down to the disk-forming region at 10 AU scale. Hence, we aim to achieve an angular resolution of 0.8", corresponding to 100 AU in these targets. The outer part (>8") of the protostellar envelopes has been probed with our SMA observations. In these ALMA observations we focus the inner <8" regions, and ACA or multiple configurations are not required.
3. Velocity Resolutions The rotational velocities in the envelopes around our targets are expected to be ~0.2 km/s at a radius of 100 AU, if the envelopes are spinning up. Hence, a spectral relsotuion of 122 kHz, resulting in a velocity resolution of ~0.17 is required to measure the rotational motions. If the envelopes are spinning down, with the proposed ALMA observations we can put 10 times more stringent constraints on the specific angular momenta of the envelope rotation at 100 AU scale, as compared to our SMA results.
4. Sensitivity We aim to achieve S/N of 10 to measure the rotational profiles down to 10 AU scale. The expected C18O (2-1) line intensity per beam is estimated from our SMA C18O (2-1) results assuming the intensity is uniformly distributed in our SMA beams.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations toward four Class 0 protostellar sources selected from our SMA sample. Our SMA results show that these Class 0 sources exhibit little envelope rotation at 1000 AU scale, and the inferred radii of Keplerian disks in these sources are <10 AU, suggesting that they are at the early stage of formation of large-scale Keplerian disks. Therefore, these are excellent targets to study how large-scale Keplerian disks seen around T Tauri stars are formed. With the proposed observations, we aim to reveal the radial profiles of rotational velocities and hence the angular momentum transfer from the outer envelopes at hundreds of AU scale to the inner 10 AU disk-forming regions in these Class 0 sources. We have calculated theoretical radial profiles of rotational motion including the effect of magnetic field. We will compare the observed and theoretical rotational profiles, and discuss that the growth of Keplerian disks from 10 AU to 100 AU scales at the early stage of star formation is ongoing, as expected in the conventional picture of star formation, or is suppressed, as predicted in several MHD simulations by magnetic braking.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
